bibl.title: Letter from Harry L. Freer to Philip Showalter Hench, February 28, 1941

div1.p: Freer informs Hench that his office cannot find the key to the map of Columbia Barracks, Cuba. However, he suggests that a participant from the time period might be able to help. Furthermore, there is no record that a map of Camp Lazear was ever prepared.

div1.head: Letter from Harry L. Freer to Philip Showalter Hench, February 28, 1941
div1.opener:
ADDRESS REPLY TO
CHIEF OF ENGINEERS, U.S. ARMY
WASHINGTON, D.C.
REFER TO FILE NO. 314.7-1551
WAR DEPARTMENT
OFFICE OF THE CHIEF OF ENGINEERS
WASHINGTON
February 28, 1941.
7-C
Dr. Philip S. Hench,
Mayo Clinic,
Rochester, Minnesota.
Dear Sir:
div1.p:
Following the receipt of your letter of February 24,
1941, a representative of this Office made a thorough search
of all known available sources, including those mentioned by
you, but was unable to find a key to the identification of
the buildings at Columbia Barracks, Cuba, shown on the map
in your possession. However, in the course of the investi-
gation it was learned that Captain Thomas M. England, U. S. A.,
Retired, one of the survivors of those who volunteered for
the yellow fever experiment, might be able to render you some
help in your inquiry. Captain England is understood to be
living at 1715 East Long Street, Columbus, Ohio, and the
information is sent in the hope that it may be of assistance
to you.

Copies of the maps previously furnished of Columbia
Barracks are being forwarded, in triplicate, under separate
cover, for your convenience. A thorough search was made of
the records from which the Annual Report of the Adjutant
General's Office for 1901 was compiled, and no record was
found of the map to which you refer. There is no record
available to indicate that a map of Camp Lazear was ever
prepared. I am sorry that I could not find just what you
needed. The copy of your informative paper has been read
with much interest and is returned herewith as you requested.
div1.closer:
Very respectfully, Harry L. Freer,
Chief Clerk. Inclosures:
Under Separate Cover.
